case_vignette: A 20-year-old man presents with 2 months of hair loss. He says that approximately 8 months ago, he was involved in a motor vehicle accident which resulted in several fractures and a difficult recovery. He has noticed clumps of hair coming out in the shower and on his pillow. He denies scalp itch. He denies any recent infections or genital sores.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been losing a lot of hair, especially when I shower or when I wake up, I find clumps of hair on my pillow.
Is this hair loss gradual or sudden, and has it been ongoing for a long time?
The hair loss has been happening for about 2 months.
Have you noticed any scalp itching, redness, or inflammation?
No, I haven't had any itch or redness on my scalp.

Have you recently experienced any stressors, such as a new job, relationship issues, or major life changes?

**Final Diagnosis:** Androgenetic Alopecia (Male or Female Pattern Baldness) if no other causes are identified.
